'''Asleep at the Wheel''' is an American [[country music|Western Swing music]] group that was formed in [[Paw Paw, West Virginia]],<ref name="Official Web Site">{{cite web|url=http://www.asleepatthewheel.com/set_story.html |title=Asleep at the Wheel Official Site |website=Asleepatthewheel.com |access-date=November 28, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010070656/http://www.asleepatthewheel.com/set_story.html |archive-date=October 10, 2007 }}</ref> and is based in [[Austin, Texas]]. The band has won nine Grammy Awards since their 1970 inception, released over twenty albums, and has charted more than 21 singles on the ''Billboard'' country charts. Their highest-charting single, "[[The Letter That Johnny Walker Read]]", peaked at No. 10 in 1975.

==History==
===Beginnings to Austin===
In 1969, [[Ray Benson]] and [[Lucky Oceans]] (Reuben Gosfield) co-founded Asleep at the Wheel in Paw Paw, West Virginia, and soon after they found themselves opening for [[Alice Cooper]] and [[Hot Tuna]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="Official Web Site"/> A year later, they moved to [[East Oakland, California]], at the invitation of [[Commander Cody and His Lost Planet Airmen]].<ref name="allmusicguide">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1509|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic – Asleep at the Wheel|access-date=December 12, 2007|website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> After being mentioned in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine by [[Van Morrison]], they landed a record deal with [[United Artists]].<ref name="allmusicguide"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/vanmorrison/articles/story/5939314/van_morrison|author=Grissim Jr., John|title=Van Morrison: The Rolling Stone interview|date=June 22, 1972|publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=April 13, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211150105/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/vanmorrison/articles/story/5939314/van_morrison|archive-date=December 11, 2007|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 1973, their debut album, ''[[Comin' Right at Ya]]'', was released by United Artists. At the invitation of [[Willie Nelson]], they left Oakland for Austin in 1974.<ref name="Official Web Site"/>

===1974–1979===
In 1974, Asleep at the Wheel released its [[Asleep at the Wheel (album)|self-titled second album]], with a cover of [[Louis Jordan]]'s "[[Choo Choo Ch'Boogie]]", which was the band's first single to hit the country charts. The following year had the release of ''[[Texas Gold]]'', with the top-ten Country hit single "The Letter That Johnny Walker Read". In addition, they played on [[PBS]]'s ''[[Austin City Limits]]'', where they have since performed a record-setting 10 times.<ref name="Official Web Site"/> In 1977, the band was voted Best Country Western Band by ''Rolling Stone'' and was awarded the Touring Band of the Year by the [[Academy of Country Music]]. They also went on tour with [[Emmylou Harris]] in Europe.<ref name="Official Web Site"/> The following year, they recorded a cover of [[Count Basie]]'s song "[[One O'Clock Jump]]".<ref name="allmusicguide"/> Also in 1980, they appeared in the movie ''[[Roadie (1980 film)|Roadie]]'', along with [[Meat Loaf]], [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]], and [[Art Carney]]. By the end of the decade, the band recorded their first live album, ''Served Live'', at the [[Austin Opera House]].<ref name="Official Web Site"/>

===1980–1989===
The 1980s became a turbulent decade for the band. After moving to [[MCA Records|MCA]], co-founder Lucky Oceans left, followed in September 1986 by Chris O'Connell due to her pregnancy. Asleep at the Wheel gathered a large amount of debt that required it to work on [[Television advertisement|commercials]] and [[movie soundtrack]]s.  This band produced the soundtrack for the film ''[[Liar's Moon]]''.

In 1985, the band released a virtually ignored self-titled album.<ref name="allmusicguide"/> By the late 1980s, Ray Benson had done some producing, allowing the band a second chance with [[Epic Records]]. In 1987, the band released ''10'', which won them their second Grammy for Best Country Instrumental, helping to launch their comeback. The album also had contributions from legendary fiddle player and onetime [[Texas Playboys]] member [[Johnny Gimble]].<ref name="allmusicguide"/> The following year, the band released ''Western Standard Time'', which won them another Grammy for Best Country Instrumental.<ref name="allmusicguide"/> The late 1980s also had the growth of [[Jann Browne]] as a solo vocalist in the group; she would later embark on a solo career on [[Curb Records]].<ref>{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1538|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jann Browne biography |access-date=January 7, 2008 |last=Deming |first=Mark |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>

===1990–1999===
The band moved to [[Arista Records]] and released the album, ''Keepin' Me Up Nights''. Soon after, the band had turnover. Among its new members was former solo singer [[Rosie Flores]], who joined in 1997.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2213&dat=19970412&id=JagkAAAAIBAJ&pg=2228,1441285 |title=Country singer Rosie Flores joins Asleep at the Wheel |newspaper=Calhoun Times and Gordon County News |date=April 12, 1997 |first=Mario |last=Tarradell |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419005441/https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2213&dat=19970412&id=JagkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bjoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2228,1441285 |archive-date=April 19, 2016 |url-status=live |page=17}}</ref> In 1991, Ray Benson directed the music<ref name="Official Web Site"/> and co-starred in the movie ''[[Wild Texas Wind]]'' with [[Dolly Parton]].<ref name="IMDB">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103263/|title=Wild Texas Wind|website=IMDb.com|access-date=December 12, 2007}}</ref> In honor of the 66th anniversary of [[U.S. Route 66|Route 66]], the band launched the ''Route 66 Tour''.<ref name="Official Web Site"/> In 1993, the band released an instant hit with several guest musicians,<ref name="Official Web Site"/> ''A Tribute to the Music of Bob Wills and the Texas Playboys'', to much critical acclaim.<ref name="allmusicguide"/> Two years later, the band celebrated their 25th anniversary<ref name="Official Web Site"/> by releasing ''The Wheel Keeps on Rollin''.<ref name="allmusicguide"/> In 1999, the band and [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]] released ''Ride with Bob'', as their second tribute album to [[Bob Wills]]. This album also enjoyed immediate success and garnered the band two Grammy wins, one for Best Country Instrumental,<ref name="Official Web Site"/> and the other for Best Package Design.

According to ''Rolling Stone'' magazine, Ray Benson "didn't just enlist the obvious Wills fans" in this tribute album to Bob Wills like [[Merle Haggard]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[Lyle Lovett]]. He also brought in some of country's young lions the [[Dixie Chicks]], [[Tim McGraw]], and [[Lee Ann Womack]], some [[pop (music)|pop]] stars", including [[Shawn Colvin]], the [[Squirrel Nut Zippers]], and fellow country preservationists such as [[Dwight Yoakam]].<ref name="Dansby">[https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/asleepatthewheel/articles/story/5924982/asleep_at_the_wheel_proves_bob_wills_is_still_the_king] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210200733/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/asleepatthewheel/articles/story/5924982/asleep_at_the_wheel_proves_bob_wills_is_still_the_king|date=December 10, 2007}}</ref>

===2000–present===
In 2000, the Dixie Chicks were nominated for an award for Vocal Event of the Year for "[[Roly Poly (Bob Wills song)|Roly Poly]]" with Asleep at the Wheel from the Country Music Association.<ref name="Front Page">{{Cite web|url=https://contactanycelebrity.com/cac/contact-the-dixie-chicks/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515102433/http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/content/awardsandaccolades.html|url-status=dead|title=Contact The Dixie Chicks (2021) [Email, Address, Agent, Manager & Publicist]|archive-date=May 15, 2008|access-date=August 13, 2021}}</ref> That same year, the band toured with [[Bob Dylan]] and [[George Strait]]. Benson recorded a tribute to Wills and Texas swing music, including Dwight Yoakam, [[Vince Gill]], Merle Haggard, the Dixie Chicks, and Willie Nelson.<ref name="Official Web Site"/><ref name="NPR">{{cite web|author=Morning Edition |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1065297 |title=Western Swing |publisher=NPR |date=October 14, 1999 |access-date=December 12, 2015}}</ref> They were scheduled to play at the White House on the fateful September 11, 2001.<ref name="Official Web Site"/> In 2003, the band released ''Live at [[Billy Bob's Texas]]'', and by the end of the decade, the band had released two more albums: ''Reinventing the Wheel'', an entirely new set of songs, including a collaboration with [[The Blind Boys of Alabama]], and a two-disc set ''Kings of Texas Swing''.<ref name="Barnes and Noble">{{cite web|url=http://music.barnesandnoble.com/search/product.asp?z=y&EAN=741157168327&itm=2|title=Kings of Texas Swing|website=Music.barnesandnoble.com|access-date=December 12, 2007}}</ref> In 2007, their second Christmas album was released, ''Santa Loves to Boogie''.

Asleep at the Wheel received six Austin Music Awards for their efforts in 2007, including Band of the Year, Songwriter of the Year (Benson), Country Band of the Year, Record Producer of the Year (Benson), Male Vocals of the Year (Benson), and Acoustic Guitar Player of the Year (McQueen).<ref name="Austin Music Awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Awards/MusicAwards?Year=2006|title=Austin Music Awards|access-date=May 9, 2008| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080502151134/http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Awards/MusicAwards?Year=2006| archive-date= May 2, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref>

==Members==
{{main|List of Asleep at the Wheel members}}
'''Current members'''
*[[Ray Benson]] – lead vocals, lead guitar {{small|(1970–present)}}
*Jason Baczynski – drums, percussion (2022–2023)
*Katie Shore – co-lead vocals, fiddle {{small|(2014–present)}}
*Dennis Ludiker – fiddle, mandolin, backing vocals {{small|(2016–present)}}
*Connor Forsyth – piano, organ, accordion, backing vocals {{small|(2016–present)}}
*Josh Hoag – bass {{small|(2017–present)}}
*Flavio Pasquetto – steel guitars {{small|(2019–present)}}
*Joey Colarusso – saxophone {{small|(2021–present)}}
*Russ Patterson- Drums (June 2023–present)

==Awards and nominations==
Asleep at the Wheel have won eight [[Grammy Awards]] out of 27 nominations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/asleep-wheel/8283|title=Asleep At The Wheel|date=November 23, 2020|website=Grammy.com|access-date=August 13, 2021}}</ref> They have also been nominated for 12 [[Country Music Association Awards]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cmaawards.com/past-winners-and-nominees/|title=CMA Awards Past Winners & Nominees|website=Cmaawards.com|access-date=August 13, 2021}}</ref> In 1977, they won the [[Academy of Country Music Award]] for Touring Band of the Year and have been nominated an additional nine times.<ref>[https://www.acmcountry.com/winners?awardTitle=Asleep+at+the+Wheel&awardCategory=&awardYear=&actionButton=Submit] {{dead link|date=August 2021}}</ref>
